conclusion: The terminal voltage of the power supply varies linearly with the current in the main circuit.
The graph in Figure 2 shows terminal voltage at point A is 4 V when current is 0 A.
The electromotive force (E) of the power supply is 4 V since there is no current flowing and hence no voltage drop across the internal resistance.
To find the internal resistance (r), we need to determine the slope of the line in the graph.
Point A has coordinates (0 A, 4 V) and point B has coordinates (0.8 A, 0 V).
The slope (m) is calculated as -5 Ω using the change in voltage divided by the change in current.
The negative sign indicates that the voltage decreases as the current increases.
The internal resistance (r) of the power supply is 5 Ω, which is the absolute value of the slope.
The electromotive force (E) of the power supply is 4 V, and the internal resistance (r) is 5 Ω.
